title: ACCC probe into Barro stake in Adelaide Brighton
text:
The Barro Group has used creep provisions in the past few years to build its stake in Adelaide Brighton to 43 per cent, and now has three representatives on the Adelaide Brighton board including the chairman's position, held by Raymond Barro.

Mr Barro has been a director of Adelaide Brighton since 2008.

Barro Group last lifted its stake in Adelaide Brighton in September, 2018.

The ACCC acknowledges that the Barro stake of 43 per cent is still a minority shareholding, but it could still have the effect of substantially lessening competition in a market.

A market enquiries letter from the ACCC said it wanted responses from market players by November 14.

"The ACCC’s investigation is focused on the impact on competition,'' the letter said.

Barro's pre-mixed concrete business in Queensland operates under a range of brands including Pronto Concrete, Gladstone Premix, Hervey Bay Ready

Mix, Townsville Concrete and Mt Cotton Concrete.

Barro also operates quarries in Victoria, NSW and Queensland.

Advertisement

Adelaide Brighton told the ASX on Friday that its own board had established a governance framework in May, 2005 to apply to ''interactions between the business interests of the Barro Group and Adelaide Brighton'' and that had been updated in March this year.

"Adelaide Brighton considers that the products and locations in which it and Barro Group do compete are limited, with the businesses having largely complementary geographic footprints,'' the company told the ASX.

The company, which generates about one third of its sales of cement and concrete from the residential market, made a $17.9 million interim loss in the first half of calendar 2019.

Adelaide Brighton also scrapped its first-half dividend.

Chief executive Nick Miller has embarked on a $30 million cost-cutting blitz in the face of softening conditions.

He is slicing into administrative functions, importing more cement and using its transport fleet better. About $10 million of the proposed savings will flow through to the bottom line in 2020. It will also sell off surplus land holdings.

Mr Miller said in late August that Adelaide Brighton would evaluate the Barro assets like any other potential acquisition opportunities if it did decide to go down that path.

"The Barro assets are no different to any other set of strategic assets,'' he said at the time.
description: The ACCC is investigating whether Barro's 43pc stake in Adelaide Brighton influences competition, particularly in ready-mix concrete.
